hero.title: Cultivating Connections, Harvesting Prosperity
hero.subtitle: We are on a mission to digitize and connect the global agricultural supply chain, empowering every stakeholder from the soil to the shelf.

vision.title: Our Vision for a Connected Future
vision.p1: DamDoh was born from a simple yet powerful idea: that technology can bridge the gaps in the agricultural world. We envision a world where smallholder farmers have direct access to global markets, where buyers can source produce with verifiable trust, and where knowledge flows freely to create a more sustainable and equitable food system.
vision.p2: We are more than just a platform; we are a community dedicated to solving real-world challenges with innovative, user-centric solutions.

challenge.title: The Fragmented Landscape of Agriculture
challenge.description: The agricultural supply chain is complex and often disconnected, presenting numerous challenges for everyone involved.

list.knowledge: Information Gaps: Farmers lack access to modern techniques and real-time market data.
list.market: Market Access: Smallholders struggle to connect with larger, more profitable markets.
list.quality: Quality & Trust: Buyers face uncertainty about produce quality, origin, and farming practices.
list.logistics: Inefficient Logistics: Poor coordination leads to high costs and significant post-harvest losses.
list.financial: Financial Exclusion: Lack of formal records prevents access to credit and insurance.
list.climate: Climate Change: Increasing unpredictability requires more resilient farming systems.
list.informal: Informal Economy: A lack of digital records hinders growth and formalization.

solution.title: The DamDoh Solution: An Integrated Ecosystem
solution.description: We tackle these challenges by providing a single, unified platform with tools for everyone.

p2p.title: Peer-to-Peer
p2p.content: Farmers connecting with other farmers to share knowledge and form cooperatives.

p2b.title: Producer-to-Business
p2b.content: Direct links between farmers and buyers, processors, and exporters, cutting out unnecessary middlemen.

p2e.title: Producer-to-Expert
p2e.content: Access to agronomists, financial advisors, and logistics providers to improve operations.

p2w.title: Producer-to-World
p2w.content: Enabling smallholder farmers to participate in the global marketplace with trust and transparency.

commitment.title: Join Our Growing Ecosystem
commitment.p1: Our commitment is to the people who feed the world. By providing the digital tools they need, we believe we can foster a more resilient, profitable, and sustainable agricultural sector for generations to come.
commitment.p2: Whether you're planting a seed, buying in bulk, or financing a farm, you have a place in the DamDoh community.

recipeData.name: Fermented Plant Juice (FPJ)
recipeData.description: A potent growth enhancer made from the fermented sap of fast-growing plants.
ingredients: 1kg fast-growing plant parts (e.g., sweet potato tips, bamboo shoots)
steps: Collect plants before sunrise. Do not wash.
Roughly chop plants.
Mix with an equal weight of brown sugar.
Pack tightly in a breathable container, fill 2/3 full.
Cover with cloth, store in a cool, dark place for ~7 days.
recipeData.usage: Dilute 1:500 to 1:1000 with water for foliar spray or soil drench.

recipeData.name: Fish Amino Acid (FAA)
recipeData.description: A nitrogen-rich fertilizer made from fermented fish parts, great for vegetative growth.
steps: Chop fish parts.
Layer fish and brown sugar in a container (2/3 full).
Cover and let ferment for 3-6 months in a cool, dark place.
recipeData.usage: Dilute 1:1000 with water, primarily for soil drenching.

recipeData.name: Water-Soluble Calcium (WCA)
recipeData.description: Provides essential calcium for fruiting and flowering stages.
steps: Roast eggshells until lightly browned, then crush into a powder.
Add eggshell powder to a jar.
Pour vinegar over powder (10 parts vinegar to 1 part eggshell by volume).
Bubbles will form. It's ready when bubbling stops (~7-10 days).
recipeData.usage: Dilute 1:1000 with water. Use as a foliar spray during flowering/fruiting.

familyFarmPage.title: The 200sqm Integrated Family Farm Model
familyFarmPage.description: A blueprint for a self-sufficient, high-yield, small-scale farming system.
familyFarmPage.intro: This model integrates various agricultural practices to create a closed-loop, regenerative system on just 200 square meters. It is designed to provide food security, nutritional diversity, and a potential income stream for a family, all while improving the environment.
familyFarmPage.diagramCaption: Conceptual layout of the integrated farm model.

conclusion.title: A Model of Resilience and Abundance
content: This 200sqm model demonstrates that even with limited space, it is possible to create a highly productive and sustainable agricultural system.
By integrating various elements and focusing on soil health, resource recycling, and biodiversity, a family can significantly enhance their food security and economic well-being.
DamDoh is committed to sharing and supporting models like this to empower communities worldwide.

zones.title: Overall Layout & Design
description: The 200sqm (e.g., 10m x 20m) plot is designed for maximum efficiency and synergy between components. The layout minimizes wasted space and places related elements close to each other to reduce labor.

details.title: Zoning
content: The farm is divided into zones: residential (Zone 0), intensive vegetable beds (Zone 1), poultry/small livestock (Zone 2), and a perimeter for fruit trees/living fences (Zone 3).

details.title: Water Management
content: A central water collection point (rainwater harvesting tank) is crucial. Swales and contour planting can be used to manage water flow and prevent erosion.

zones.title: Intensive Vegetable Beds
zones.imageAlt: Raised vegetable beds with diverse crops
description: The core food production area. Utilizes biointensive methods like raised beds, close spacing, and succession planting to maximize yield in a small area. This area provides the family's daily vegetable needs.

details.title: Crop Rotation
content: Crops are rotated between beds each season to prevent nutrient depletion and pest buildup. (e.g., Legumes -> Leafy Greens -> Root Vegetables -> Fruiting Vegetables).

details.title: Companion Planting
content: Beneficial plants are grown together. For example, planting marigolds to deter nematodes or basil near tomatoes to improve flavor and repel pests.

details.title: Vertical Gardening
content: Trellises and vertical structures are used for climbing plants like beans, cucumbers, and passion fruit to save ground space.

zones.title: Small Livestock Integration
zones.imageAlt: A small chicken coop and a fish pond
description: A small flock of chickens (5-10) and a mini fish pond (aquaponics) are integrated. Chickens provide eggs and meat, while their manure is a key ingredient for compost. The fish provide protein, and their nutrient-rich water can be used to fertilize plants.

details.title: Chicken Tractor
content: A movable coop ('chicken tractor') can be used to till and fertilize vegetable beds between plantings.

details.title: Aquaponics System
content: Water from the fish pond, rich in ammonia, is pumped to grow beds where bacteria convert it to nitrates, which fertilize the plants. The clean water is then returned to the fish.

zones.title: Compost & Nutrient Recycling
zones.imageAlt: A three-bin compost system with kitchen scraps and yard waste
description: This is the heart of the farm's fertility. All organic 'waste'—kitchen scraps, animal manure, crop residues, and weeds—is composted. This creates a closed-loop system, eliminating the need for external chemical fertilizers and improving soil health year after year.

details.title: Compost System
content: A simple three-bin system allows for continuous production: one bin for adding new material, one for active composting, and one for finished compost.

details.title: Vermicomposting
content: A worm farm (vermicompost) can be added to process kitchen scraps even faster, producing valuable worm castings and 'worm tea' fertilizer.

zones.title: Integration with FGW Principles
zones.imageAlt: A field covered in thick mulch, known as God's Blanket.
description: This model heavily incorporates principles from Farming God's Way (FGW) to ensure sustainability and high yields with minimal external inputs.

subSections.title: No Tillage
content: The vegetable beds are permanent and are never tilled. This protects the soil structure and the delicate web of microbial life within it.

subSections.title: God's Blanket
content: All soil surfaces are kept covered with a thick layer of organic mulch (e.g., straw, wood chips, leaves) at all times. This conserves moisture, suppresses weeds, and feeds the soil as it decomposes.

subSections.title: High Standards
content: All tasks are done with excellence and on time. This includes timely planting, consistent watering, active composting, and prompt harvesting to maximize the potential of the small plot.

seedStartingPage.title: The Ultimate Guide to Starting Seeds Indoors
seedStartingPage.description: Give your crops a head start and extend your growing season by mastering the art of starting seeds indoors.
seedStartingPage.intro: Starting seeds indoors is a rewarding process that can lead to healthier plants and earlier harvests. By controlling the initial environment, you protect your seedlings from pests, diseases, and unpredictable weather. This guide covers the essentials to get you started.

sections.title: Why Start Seeds Indoors?
sections.intro: Starting seeds inside offers several key advantages over direct sowing in the garden.

points.def: Start weeks or months before your last frost date, allowing crops that require a long season (like tomatoes and peppers) to mature.
You can control temperature, moisture, and light to create the perfect conditions for seeds to sprout.
Young, vulnerable seedlings are protected from cutworms, slugs, and fungal diseases common in cool, damp spring soil.
A packet of seeds is far cheaper than buying individual plant starts from a nursery.

sections.title: Essential Supplies
sections.intro: You don't need expensive equipment, but having the right supplies makes a huge difference.

points.def: Choose high-quality seeds appropriate for your climate and growing season.
Use seed starting trays, peat pots, soil blocks, or even recycled containers like yogurt cups (ensure they have drainage holes).
Use a sterile, lightweight mix designed for starting seeds. Avoid heavy garden soil, which can harbor diseases and compact easily.
A sunny, south-facing window can work, but a simple shop light with fluorescent or LED bulbs provides more consistent, direct light and prevents 'leggy' seedlings.
A spray bottle or a gentle watering can to water seedlings without dislodging them.
Beneficial for heat-loving plants like peppers and eggplants to speed up germination.

sections.title: Step-by-Step Planting Process
sections.intro: Follow these steps for successful seed starting:
steps: Moisten Your Mix: Before filling your containers, put your seed starting mix in a tub and slowly add warm water until it's damp but not waterlogged, like a wrung-out sponge.
Fill Containers: Fill your containers with the moistened mix and gently tamp it down. Do not compact it tightly.
Sow Seeds: Plant seeds to the depth recommended on the seed packet. A general rule is to plant a seed twice as deep as it is wide. Place 2-3 seeds per cell or pot.
Cover & Label: Lightly cover the seeds with more mix. Label your containers clearly with the crop name and planting date.
Water Gently: Water the surface gently with your spray bottle to ensure good seed-to-soil contact.
Provide Warmth: Cover the trays with a plastic dome or plastic wrap to retain humidity. Place them in a warm spot or on a heat mat until they germinate.

sections.title: Caring for Your Seedlings
sections.intro: Once your seeds sprout, their needs change.
steps: Provide Light: As soon as the first seedlings emerge, remove the plastic cover and place them under direct light. Keep lights just 2-3 inches above the tops of the plants for 14-16 hours a day.
Water Correctly: Keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. It's best to water from the bottom by placing your trays in a shallow pan of water. This encourages strong root growth.

Thin Seedlings: Once the seedlings have their first set of 'true leaves' (the second set that appears), choose the strongest seedling in each cell and snip the others at the soil line with scissors. Do not pull them out, as this can disturb the roots of the remaining seedling.
Fertilize Lightly: After 3-4 weeks, you can begin feeding your seedlings with a half-strength liquid organic fertilizer, such as fish emulsion or compost tea, once a week.

sections.title: Hardening Off & Transplanting
sections.intro: This is a critical step to acclimate your indoor-grown plants to the outdoor environment.
steps: Start Gradually: About 7-10 days before you plan to plant them in the garden, start taking your seedlings outside. Begin with just 1-2 hours in a shady, protected spot.
Increase Exposure: Each day, gradually increase the amount of time they spend outside and slowly introduce them to more direct sunlight and wind.
Reduce Water: Slightly reduce watering during this period, but don't let them wilt completely.
Transplant: After 7-10 days of hardening off, choose an overcast day or late afternoon to transplant your seedlings into the garden. Water them in well immediately after planting.
